content.description:
Head up the mellow slab to the crack emanating from the squat roof. Follow this crack out right, climbing the face just left of the arete before finishing on a small ledge at a set of chains. Multiple creative kneebars might make things less rushed for those with tinier forearms.

Imposing diagonal crack along the face to the right of Air Test.
10 bolts and chains.

Sustained climbing on edges between good rests lead to the very top of great white. There are three “cruxes” though there is debate about which is the true crux. They say the first pitch goes at 12c, but you’d be silly to stop there! Ensure you have an 80m rope to get the full experience.

Solo up the slab at the base of the teen wall and start up the cracks on the left side of the wall.
Bolts w/ fixed draws.

To the first set of anchors on Air Test. (This climb merits a separate entry, being classic in it's own right, and also being more moderate in difficulty and thus attracting a larger crowd of [mortal] climbers).



Starts up the slab like the rest of the "test" pieces (see what I did there).


Bolts + anchor.

The first 2/3 of the route is just climbing Wings of Desire. Really committing move out right from the blocky ledge onto an overhanging flaring crack feature. The movement is pumpy and fairly sustained, with a key just around the third bolt. Solid hand jamming technique can make a clip easier when moving up to the roof. Very sloped holds and nothing overly positive to grab. You'll be wishing for a crimp. 

Once you stand up from the roof of the first half of Wings of Desire, you'll see the anchors up to your right. The crux is still ahead, just before the anchor. All the holds remain sloped, with a key 2-3 finger crimp for your left hand on the crux just before the anchor. 

Cleaning the route is kind of a pain, be sure you know how to clean a traversing, overhung route. Feel extremely proud if you pull off the onsight!



Climb the bolts for Wings of Desire before trending right above the first roof. Start by scrambling up the large block to clip the high first bolt. The most obvious line when looking at the Great White wall from across the valley.

Well bolted throughout. 8 bolts and a 2 bolt rap ring equipped anchor.

The extension to Acid Test adds a short power endurance section on slopy edges followed by a tricky roof boulder. This long and airy pitch is surely one of the best Skaha has to offer. 

35m
22 bolts, though some can be skipped or extended to reduce rope drag for the last bit.



Extension to Acid Test. 

7 more bolts, 22 in total.

Often overlooked route at Great White that features thin moves and fun technical climbing, top is easier but with trickier route finding 



First route right of Gang Bang that follows a thin face with some finger locks

9 bolts

climb easy crack 1st pitch (5.6) to top of blocks.  (10a) 2nd pitch starts off a little in your face before easing off mid-way.

3 climbs to the right of the classic Gang Bang (the unmistakable right corner crack)
6 bolts per pitch with anchors.  can rap down all the way with a 60m rope (barely so tie knots)

Can be climbed as 1 or 2 pitches. Recommended to belay from the anchor chains or Air Test if doing as 2 pitches.
Start up a wide crack below the Teen Wall. Then follow the crack, getting steeper and steeper. Rap from the big ledge down to the ground on a 70m, or to the anchor of Overedger and perform a second rap if on a 60m.
Alternatively traverse along the ledge and finish up Gang Bang.

Sarts on bolted slab below Teen wall. Traverse up and left below the anchor chains of Air Test.
Standard Skaha trad rack

Eyrily Hanging Out is one of a small number of excellent traditional climbs at Skaha, and is highly recommended.  
  
 Scramble up to the top of a pedestal and then climb the finger crack through a short crux section (~5.10c). A lower angled crack leads easily to the roofs, which are bypassed to the right via laybacks, underclings, and face holds.  
  
 There is a two bolt rappel anchor on a ledge midway through the roofs. I stopped here and was able to reach the ground with a 70m rope. I'm not sure if a 60m would have made it. Based on the presence of lichen and minimal chalk above, I suspect most people finish the climb here also.  
  
 To this point, the climbing through the roofs is probably not more than 5.10a, and so by stopping at this anchor the climb is nowhere near as difficult as the 5.11a rating it gets in the guidebook. 
  
 It's possible to continue through the final roof to the top of the wall, and I suspect the true crux is this final roof section.

Located at the south end of Great White Wall, near and right of the immensely popular Test of the Ironman, Eyrily Hanging Out climbs the large inside corner through two roofs.
Eyrily Hanging Out is very well protected with a rack of cams and nuts from tips to #1 Camalot, with doubles in finger sizes. Include a large number of extendable draws.

Start on the obvious crack then up into the dihedral and a final boulder problem. Awesome!



next route right of skin of a lion

Bolts

Fun Run is one of a small number of excellent traditional climbs at Skaha, and is highly recommended.  
  
                        Fun Run 5.10a and Eyrily Hanging Out 5.11a       
  
 Scramble up to the top of a large pedestal/platform, then climb the thin corner via jams, lay backs, and stemming. A roof provides the crux, and then the difficulties ease as the angle lessens. At the end another roof provides the mental crux, and is bypassed on the left. 
  
                        Neena follows Fun Run on Great White wall, Skaha       
  
 Belay from just below the top on a small ledge at a chain anchor, or on the top of the wall from a tree.  
  
 Descend via rappel. A 40 metre rappel will reach the ground. Alternately a 35 metre reaches an anchor just above the ground on the route Test of the Ironman. A second short rappel reaches the ground. Alternately a 7 metre rappel reaches the upper anchors of Test of the Ironman and then a second rappel of 35 metres reaches the ground. It is also possible to walk off to the north from the top of the crag.

Located at the south end of Great White Wall, near and right of the immensely popular Test of the Ironman, Fun Run climbs a crack up and left to a roof system at the top of the wall. Located just to the right of the route Violator, and to the left of the obvious Eerily Hanging Out.
With the exception of the roof at the end, which is a bit run out, Fun Run protects very well. The emphasis is on small cams and nuts. Bring many long slings to mitigate rope drag.

The obvious dihedral between Air Test wall and Wings of Desire wall. Feels a little soft for 10d.



The dihedral between Air Test wall and Wings of Desire wall

to Camalot 4

A couple clips of good face climbing leads to a fun arete.  Fun hand jams provide respite before a balancy arete.  If the barn dooring doesn’t get you then the pump just might.  

10 feet left of the prominent right facing corner (Horseshoes...) near Painted Bird.  
Bolts

climbs.name: In the Skin of a Lion

content.description:
The real business starts a little over a third of the way up the route with an awkward reach into a left facing flake.  Hang on through the flake until a solid rest.  After the rest comes a building crux sequence that doesn’t let up until the chains.  Some fun finger locks give way to an awkward clip and laybacking into a crimpy sequence. Mentally challenging because of the sustained nature and building pump until the end.  Not grabbing the chains is a challenge in itself. 

10 ft left of the massive right facing corner that is home to Gang Bang
8 bolts

climbs.name: Logan's Run
climbs.fa: Randy Atkinson, Tim Ryan, Dean Hart 1992

content.description: No text - use the 'Improve This Page' link to add something useful!

Clever route name!  Start up Hogopogo until the fourth clip and then head straight up.  Thin feet and hard crimping lockoffs make this crux seem hard for the grade.  Good movement though.  An added bonus is that you get to finish on the fun crux sequence of Painted Bird.  

Approx 5 ft left of the obvious right facing dihedral (Horseshoes...). 
12 bolts

P1. Stem and jam up the corner.  Large blocks at the bottom may be loose, but the rock quality is very good after that. The crux comes near the top. Belay off a bolted anchor on a large sloping ledge. We chose to top out. But if you plan to rappel from here, bring up a second rope.  

P2. Compared to the first pitch, P2 is significantly shorter and the rock quality becomes more suspect under the roof. But there's more jams and stems, and a big roof to finish. We didn't find any fixed anchor at the top, except for a single rusty piton, but there are plenty of cracks that will take hand size gear.

Both pitches are 5.8+ to 5.9, depending on how you feel about jams and stems.

This route starts immediately left of Wings of Desire, at the base of the big right facing corner with the large loose blocks near the bottom.
Standard rack. Bolted anchor for P1. Build your own gear anchor for P2.

climbs.name: Painted Bird
climbs.fa: Rosemary Kajioka 1995...extension to original Larry Ostrander route

content.description:
Pick your way through fun climbing until the final moves.  Be patient as the business is at the end.  The end can be done statically but I went for a two dyno sequence.  According to Marc’s guide, The Painted Bird is a controversial 1965 novel by Jerry Kosinski, which describes World War 2 as seen by a gypsy boy.  Probably a good read for literate climbers.  

Can’t miss it.  Located directly behind the large fir tree. 
12 bolts

Solo up the slab to the fixed chain right in the middle of the teen wall. The climb goes straight up to a boulder problem at the third bolt, followed by a tricky move at the fourth. Rest on the big rail and stare up at the crux of the route just before the midway anchor. If you fire the crux don't stop there, keep climbing up the sustained boulder problems with poor rests. You finally achieve some big holds and rest, but just when you thought it was over the slopers just above the last bolt will shut you down!

High quality, engaging climbing with a little bit of everything! CLASSIC!

Watch out for climbers on Acid Test as the fall from the crux can easily land just before Acid Test starts traversing right

Right in the middle of the teen wall
15 bolts

A cryptic route best attempted in the morning when shaded. Start on jugs and pull the small roof to establish yourself on a compact ledge. Crimp your way up to more relaxed climbing, saving a bit of power for the finish.

From Wings of Desire, follow the wall around the corner to the right and walk a few metres up the hill until you're at the base of a dihedral. Shadowlands starts below the roof to your left on stone coloured green by lichen, and continues up the shallow open book.
7 bolts and chains. Long draws below the roof are nice.

climbs.name: Test of the Ironman
climbs.fa: Robin Barley, Nick Barley, Pete Shackelton (2 pitches) 1990, redesigned by Dave Lane

content.description:
From the lowest point on the arete climb an easy crack to the base of the real clmibing.

Far right side or great white wall
About 14 draws

This is a pretty fun climb that takes a right leaning line of bolts, increasing in difficulty throughout. The 2nd to 3rd bolt is pretty runout, but the climbing is easier there. Crux is near the top - a tricky sequence of footwork and sidepulls.

Heading to Great White Wall, you'll pass this route on the right before getting to Eyrily Hanging Out. Look for right-leaning bolt line starting with a black streak, a few routes right of the big tree.
Bolts. Runout between bolts 2 and 3.

Easy, but still feels uncomfortable if you fall.

5 bolts

A really fun, albeit short route that is worth doing if you're in the area. Really well protected, great holds, and athletic movement all combine to make a really fun experience.

Far right side of great white. Look for the ledgy looking route immediately left of a tree right as you arrive at the crag.
5 bolts, chain anchor.

Face climb to a tricky mantle and to some easier climbing above. Fun! 40 meters long, TIE KNOTS AT THE END OF YOUR ROPE.



Just left of Fun Run on the left part of the wall.

Bolts

One of the all-time great climbs at Skaha. A must-do. 
  
  This route follows a seam, crack, and series of features straight up through the gently overhanging wall, to a small alcove beneath a roof. Pull the roof, and you've only got to hang on for a few more meters to the chains. 
  
 This route has been lead on gear.

On the left side of the Great White Wall, just right of Logan's Run and a long ramping corner climb called Mrs Palmer. Begin by stepping rightward off a ledge, then it's straight up from there.
~14 bolts.

A distinct crux distinguishes this route from its neighbor In the Skin of a Lion.  A hard clip leads to some gaston moves into a crimping sequence. A very shouldery route that wears out your large muscle groups for the crimps ahead.  Once the crux is over you probably won’t fall off but still need to use your rests and pay attention.  The flake moves as you are gradually traversing left towards the chains actually add a lot of quality to the route.  

Continue past the large right facing dihedral for about 20 ft until the talus gives way to a sloping ledge leading up to the classic Wings of Desire. 
11 bolts
A collection of routes, many of which are on the obvious and impressive west-facing cliff. Shady in the mornings.
